metadata.title: Here’s The Expert Data Analyst You’ve Been Looking For. | by Melissa Rezza | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Here’s The Expert Data Analyst You’ve Been Looking For.
metadata.description: The Lion is considered the King of the Jungle. This is because the lion is on top of his game. Imagine if you could be on top of your Big Data game too! Well, I’ve got news for you, you can. It all…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: On average a data analyst earns $75,588 per year.
Data analytics managers earn an average pay of $109,954.

all_paragraphs: The Lion is considered the King of the Jungle. This is because the lion is on top of his game. Imagine if you could be on top of your Big Data game too! Well, I’ve got news for you, you can. It all comes down to having the right Data Analyst.
Recently, a client of mine was trying to read the data for his business and neither of us knew what we were looking at.
He wants to know exactly how the COVID-19 pandemic has affected his business and what the trajectory looks like moving forward.
For that, I suggested he hire a data analyst.
We did a Google search for what to look for in a good data analyst and let’s just say it all seemed Greek to me!
So, I did what I do best and got to researching. Here is some of what I learned.

Data analysts look at large fundamental measures of data to detect hidden patterns, statistics, and insights. With current technology, your data can be analyzed almost immediately and answers can be obtained.

Key attributes to look for in a data analyst are creativity and curiosity, among others. A great analyst will have strongly based statistical methods as well as a desire to find better explanations for what should happen next once the data is analyzed.
Applying the correct algorithms and using specific formulas while prioritizing the raw data that’s been collected helps companies make informed decisions.

The data concept has been around for years; most organizations now understand that they can apply analytics and get significant value from it if they capture all the data that streams into their business.
Some fundamental job functions of a data analyst include;
•Establishing the price of new materials for the market
•Deciding whether to reduce or hire workforce
•Sales timing and lowering transportation expenditures alongside estimating the market share.
The data analyst translates trajectories, trends, and numbers into accessible and digestible information.
As a company is gathering its data such as sales figures, inventories, profit margins, and market research, the analyst can segment each item to get specific information such as;
•Gather, evaluate, and report to meet the requirements of the business.
•Determine new methods to improve data collection, reporting and analysis.
•Establishing technical problems relating to data analysis and collection processes, and report designing.
•Estimating the challenges being proposed and assessing whether those can be answered by the data.
•Report data in a repeatable and comprehensive style.

•The analyst collects, manipulates and analyzes data. This is made possible through the use of systematic and standard methods, and formulas to evaluate the necessary information. Then, they archetypally prepare detailed reports on the results from the analysis.

•Data analysts carry out basic statistics such as averages and variations for a given item over a specific time duration. Additionally, they forecast yields as well as interpreting the underlying distribution frequency of a set of continuous data.

•They use standard techniques of analysis, collection, and reporting when completing their activities and will always safeguard the business's data, ensuring that the data outcomes generate consistent and recyclable guidance.

Data analysts are responsible for comprehending insights and trends that are indicated in the large sets of data. Therefore they are hired by companies to improve various business practices and to help make better decisions.
There are three critical steps to launching a data analyst profession.

Earning a bachelor’s degree in statistics, computer science or information technology. The study of applied statistics or minor in data science. It is also necessary to enroll in computer science classes that stress database management and project management.

It is not easy to gain meaningful employment as a data analyst without any experience. Interning while still in school is the right way to acquire the necessary knowledge and skills. Even yet, many people in technical professions begin at entry-level positions for instance as a technician or statistical assistant. Such positions offer valuable on-the-job experience and training. It is essential to get some in-house training, especially on big data management and analytical software programs. Willingness, knowledge, and expertise to learn can assist a person to their desired level.

It is essential to consider a certificate program or a master’s degree this will offer more job opportunities thus advancing your profession. Employers want job applicants who have a wealth of knowledge and are more conversant with the latest tools and technology. One should, therefore, consider a master’s degree in big data management, business data analytics or data science.

On average a data analyst earns $75,588 per year. Numerous elements influence the salary, such include level of education, involvement in a professional organization, certifications and years of experience.

Data analytics managers earn an average pay of $109,954. For the first three to ten years in this position, earnings increase somewhat; nevertheless, some individuals choose to move on to other jobs, such as data architects, data scientist or data engineers once they have amassed a ten-year experience in this profession.

Direct marketing companies would be looking for a data analyst who has proven working experiences as a business data analysts or a data scientist. They will also concentrate on technical expertise relating to data models, data mining, segmentation techniques and database design development.

They will seek a person who has a robust understanding of business objects, programming and databases, technical data methods, coupled with intensive experience on statistical programs used for datasets analysis such as SAS, SPSS and Excel.

A data analyst is similar to a data scientists. However, a data analyst is responsible for developing algorithms applied for data acquisition and discovery. Instead of formulating their data projects, the data analysts will find themselves tackling particular business activities using available tools, data sets and systems.
The two professions share the common objective of discovering how to utilize information to solve problems and answer questions for the benefits of their industry or business.
While a data scientist formulates statistical approaches and applies scientific techniques to explain data in addition to making predictions, data is collected and analyzed by a data analyst.

For example, while barometric pressure, humidity, and temperature could be obtained by the data analyst, the data scientist can apply that data and predict whether a hurricane might gather in the atmosphere.
Data analytics is used in industries like Healthcare, Gaming, Travel, Energy Management, and Direct Marketing.
Data science algorithms are used in industries like Internet Searches, Digital Advertising, and Search Recommenders.

The benefits that a data analyst brings to the table are speed and efficiency. While a business would have gathered information, conducted analytics and unearthed information a few years ago that could be used for future decisions, companies now identify insights for immediate decisions.
The ability to work faster — and stay agile — creates a competitive edge for organizations that they didn’t have before.
Here are some other benefits of having an analyst on your team.

Data analysts use data technologies such as Hadoop and cloud-based analytics bringing significant cost advantages when it comes to storing large amounts of data — plus they can identify more efficient ways of doing business.

With the speed of Hadoop and in-memory analytics, combined with the capacity to analyze new sources of data, businesses are able to analyze information immediately — and make decisions based on what they’ve learned.
With the ability to gauge customer needs and satisfaction through analytics comes the power to give customers what they want.

Data analysts help organizations harness their data and use it to identify new opportunities. That, in turn, leads to smarter business moves, more efficient operations, higher profits and happier customers.

As companies across the spectrum focus on building a data analytics strategy to stay competitive in a digitally-focused global environment, they will need a variety of data science tools capable of slicing, dicing, and operationalizing business data in numerous ways.
A well-planned and executed data strategy will make it possible for your business to make faster, business-critical decisions and to predict the results of those decisions more accurately.

This ongoing vision and innovation in the field of data science benefits a business world that is now almost exclusively data-based to drive anything from the smallest daily improvements to the most provocative and forward-thinking ideas.
Here’s what you need to know about the best available data analytics tools to help collect, store, analyze and visualize your data and incorporate machine learning power and possibilities.

The starting point for each data strategy is the collection of quality data that can be transformed into rich analysis. The right data collection tools can reduce errors and duplicates, provide greater accuracy and maintain data integrity from all sources.
The following tools for collecting data stand out:
The core of all data analysis is to find meaning in and extract value from your data.

Tools that allow you to understand and derive real meaning from your data easily help you make game-changing business decisions that affect revenue, competitiveness, innovation, customer experience, and operational efficiency.
Check out these leading data analytics tools and platforms:

Data warehouse features like combined and integrated multi-and disparate source data repositories, standardized for usability. You can search in real time and in batches for clean and stable data on any business subject.
Solutions such as Amazon Athena and S3, which work on the largest cloud structure worldwide, allow the data to be stored, collected and carried out without the need for an analytical system.
Some of the top tools for storing data today are:
Visual analytics tools identify patterns and trends in your data and help end-users understand and digest complex concepts.
It is much easier to access, understand and share visual representations of your data in the form of charts, graphs and maps.
Here are some high-performing data visualization tools:

The purpose and promise of data science is to analyze data, learn from it and make predictions about your company. The machine learning tools of today use a variety of algorithms to represent, evaluate and optimize your data so that generalizations and anomalies have been correctly interpreted.
These are some of the best machine learning tools available:
Any modern data analyst strategy’s success depends on full access to all data.

It’s essential for the data analyst to have access to a proprietary set of ETL tools (extract, transform, load) — in order to optimize and expand the charging in any form of massive amounts of data from any source into a cloud data warehouse or cloud-based storage like Amazon S3.

Once your information is transmitted to the data warehouse, you can implement any model of machine-learning you incorporated to enhance your understanding and commitment to your customers or other vital initiatives.
Now that you have a better understanding of how to become a data analyst, or what to look for when hiring one for your business, you will be exponentially ahead of the competition.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Work At Home Mom, Wife, Copywriter, Blogger, Eternal Rebel. Grateful Recovering Addict/Alcoholic
